lines: What is the Vehicle Routing Problem?
The Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP) isa combinatorial optimization problem that seeks to
determine the optimal set of routes for a fleet of vehicles to traverse in order to deliver to.a
given set of customers. It is a generalization of the famous Traveling Salesman Problem
NP-Hard Complexity: The VRP belongs to the class of NP-hard problems, meaning no
polynomial-time algorithm Is known for finding optimal solutions
Combinatorial Explosion: For n customers, there are approximately (n!)?/n possible
Multi-Objective: Typically optimizes for distance, time, cost. or vehicle utilization
Real-World Constraints: Involves practical limitations ike vehicle capacity, time
Primary Objective: Minimize total distance traveleo
Secondary Objectives: Minimize number of vehicles used minimize total duration
Constraint Satisfaction: All customers must be served while respecting vehicle
Capacity Constraints: E(demand_i)s vehicle_capacity for each route
. Distance Constraints: route distance  max distance for each vehicle
3 Duration Constraints: route _duration max_duration for each vehicle
1 Service Time: Fixed time spent at each customer location

A constructive heuristic that builds routes by always choosing the nearest unvisited
Nearest Start: Begin with closest customer to depot
Farthest Start: Begin with farthest customer to depot (for better coverage)
Time Complexity: O(n2) where  number of customers
Solution Quality: Good for small instances, may be suboptimal for larger problems
4. Repeat until all customers visited Or vehicle capacity/constraints exceeded
6. Start new route if customers remain and vehicles available

A classical VRP algorithm developed by Clarke and Wright (1964) that improves upon initial
radial routes by merging routes based on distance savings.
Savings Formula: S(i,j) = d(0,i)  d(0,;) d(i,i)
d(O,i) distance from depot to customer
d(o,i) distance from depot to customer
dCi;) = distance between customers i and
Time Complexity: O(n? log n) due to sorting savings
Space Complexity: O(n2) for savings matrix
Solution Quality: Better than greedy for medium-sized problems
